study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the role of Psyllium as a dietary fiber supplement in health maintenance, particularly its effects on cholesterol levels and its potential benefits in preventing diseases like diabetes, CAD, and colonic cancer.
results_summary: Psyllium was found to bind bile acids in the gut, preventing their reabsorption, and was effective as an adjunct therapy for mild-to-moderate hypercholesterolemia. It also provided added cholesterol-lowering benefits when combined with statins, was well tolerated, and cost-effective.
population_specificity: Patients with mild-to-moderate hypercholesterolemia.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the therapeutic value of psyllium for treating various conditions, including constipation, diarrhea, irritable bowel syndrome, inflammatory bowel disease, colon cancer, diabetes, and hypercholesterolemia, as well as its potential for drug delivery systems.
results_summary: The study found that psyllium has significant therapeutic benefits, including aiding weight control, regulating glucose levels in diabetics, reducing serum lipid levels in hyperlipidemics, and treating gastrointestinal disorders. It also highlighted psyllium's gel-forming properties for potential drug delivery applications.
population_specificity: General human population, including diabetic patients and hyperlipidemics.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of 5.1g b.i.d. of psyllium husk fiber on lipid and glucose levels in patients with type II diabetes when used as an adjunct to dietary and drug therapy.
results_summary: Psyllium significantly reduced fasting plasma glucose (FBS) and HbA1c, increased HDL-C, and decreased the LDL/HDL ratio. It was well tolerated with no serious adverse events and improved gastric tolerance to metformin.
population_specificity: Patients with type II diabetes from an outpatient primary care clinic.
interactions: Improved gastric tolerance to metformin noted.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of a combination therapy including psyllium and plant sterols on plasma lipids and lipoprotein subfractions in individuals with moderate LDL cholesterol levels.
results_summary: The study found that psyllium combined with plant sterols significantly reduced plasma total cholesterol and LDL-C, as well as the number of IDL, LDL, and HDL particles, particularly in smaller subfractions, resulting in a less atherogenic lipoprotein profile.
population_specificity: 33 healthy individuals (11 males, 22 females) aged 35-65 with BMI 25-35 kg/m² and LDL-C between 2.6-4.1 mmol/L.
effective_dosage: 7.68 g/d psyllium + 2.6 g/d plant sterols, provided via cookies.
study_duration: 4 weeks per treatment phase, with a 3-week washout period.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the hypolipidemic effects of enzymatically modified psyllium preparations to raw psyllium husks in hamsters.
results_summary: Psyllium significantly reduced plasma cholesterol levels by 50-100% compared to cellulose, with no differences between raw and modified psyllium. Fecal bile acid excretion increased by 30-70% with psyllium diets, but weight gain was lower with one modified psyllium preparation.
population_specificity: Hamsters fed cholesterol-enriched diets.
effective_dosage: 5% cellulose plus 7% psyllium preparations in the diet.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the LDL-C-lowering effect of psyllium husk when added to low-dose simvastatin therapy compared to higher-dose simvastatin alone.
results_summary: Psyllium supplementation (15 g daily) with 10 mg simvastatin was as effective in lowering LDL-C as 20 mg simvastatin alone, with no significant changes in triglycerides or HDL-C. The combination was well-tolerated and enhanced LDL-C and apolipoprotein B reduction.
population_specificity: 68 patients (specific demographics not detailed).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate how a solid-state xylanase treatment affects the physicochemical properties of psyllium, including water-uptake, gelling capacities, and fiber content.
results_summary: The xylanase treatment significantly reduced water-uptake and gelling capacities of psyllium, slightly decreased soluble fiber content, and resulted in smoother particle surfaces, while insoluble fiber content remained unchanged. The process required no special equipment and generated no waste, suggesting potential for improving psyllium's use in functional foods.
population_specificity: Not specified (in vitro study on psyllium properties)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of psyllium on metabolic control in type 2 diabetic patients, including its impact on blood glucose, cholesterol, and other biomarkers.
results_summary: Psyllium significantly reduced glucose absorption, total and LDL cholesterol, and uric acid, with modest effects on insulin and other biomarkers. No adverse effects on mineral or vitamin concentrations were observed.
population_specificity: Twenty type 2 diabetic patients (12 men, 8 women; mean age ~67 years).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine how sex and hormonal status influence the effects of psyllium supplementation on plasma lipoprotein metabolism.
results_summary: Psyllium intake decreased LDL cholesterol by 8% across all groups but had sex-specific effects on triglycerides (decreased in men, increased in postmenopausal women). Apoprotein levels and VLDL metabolism changes varied by hormonal status, suggesting differential metabolic impacts.
population_specificity: 24 men, 23 premenopausal women, and 21 postmenopausal women.
effective_dosage: 15 g psyllium per day, provided via cookies.
study_duration: 30-day treatment periods in a crossover design.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the benefits and side effects of psyllium fiber in pediatric patients with irritable bowel syndrome (IBS).
results_summary: The abstract mentions that psyllium fiber is discussed as one of the herbal remedies with potential benefits for pediatric IBS, but specific findings or outcomes are not detailed.
population_specificity: Pediatric patients with irritable bowel syndrome (IBS).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of psyllium with other dietary interventions (such as fruits and rye bread) on stool frequency and constipation-related outcomes in adults with chronic constipation.
results_summary: The study found that fruits, particularly kiwifruit, resulted in higher stool frequency compared to psyllium, while prunes showed no difference. Psyllium was used as a comparator but did not outperform certain dietary interventions.
population_specificity: Adults with chronic constipation (1714 participants across 23 studies).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy of micronized purified flavonoid fraction (with psyllium as part of standard treatment) in preventing complications like thrombosis, edema, and perianal skin tags after hemorrhoidectomy.
results_summary: Psyllium, as part of standard treatment, was compared against standard treatment plus micronized purified flavonoid fraction. The study found no additional pain relief from the flavonoid fraction, but the standard treatment (including psyllium) was effective in baseline care. The flavonoid group showed reduced thrombosis/edema and fewer skin tags, but psyllium's standalone effects were not isolated.
population_specificity: Patients who underwent hemorrhoidectomy for grade III and IV hemorrhoids.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the efficacy of two gold kiwifruits versus 10 g of psyllium in treating constipation.
results_summary: The study found that two gold kiwifruits were noninferior to 10 g of psyllium for treating constipation, suggesting comparable effectiveness. Psyllium was used as a benchmark for efficacy in this comparison.
population_specificity: Patients with constipation (specific details not provided).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to analyze the impact of dietary supplementation, including psyllium husk, on the course of Irritable Bowel Syndrome (IBS).
results_summary: The abstract suggests that psyllium husk is among the supplements considered supportive in IBS therapy, though specific efficacy details are not provided. The study highlights the lack of clear nutritional recommendations for IBS and the potential benefits of unconventional dietary approaches.
population_specificity: Individuals with Irritable Bowel Syndrome (IBS).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess psyllium's impact on body weight, BMI, and waist circumference in overweight and obese participants through a meta-analysis of randomized controlled studies.
results_summary: The meta-analysis found that psyllium, dosed before meals, significantly reduced body weight (-2.1 kg), BMI (-0.8 kg/m²), and waist circumference (-2.2 cm) in overweight and obese populations. The results were statistically significant (p < .001) and clinically relevant.
population_specificity: Overweight and obese participants
effective_dosage: Mean dose of 10.8 g/day, administered just before meals

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of psyllium husk on functional constipation symptoms and identify relevant gut microbiota modulations.
results_summary: The study found that psyllium husk, either alone or combined with wheat bran, improved functional constipation symptoms and modulated gut microbiota.
population_specificity: 250 adults with functional constipation

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine how sex and hormonal status influence the effects of Psyllium on plasma lipids, specifically LDL cholesterol and triglycerides, by examining changes in gene expression related to lipid metabolism.
results_summary: Psyllium intake significantly lowered LDL cholesterol in all groups, reduced triglycerides in men but increased them in postmenopausal women, and altered gene expression of HMG-CoA reductase and lipoprotein lipase (LPL) in a sex-dependent manner.
population_specificity: Men and pre- and post-menopausal women.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effectiveness of kiwifruit or kiwifruit extracts against non-kiwifruit controls, including psyllium, in treating constipation.
results_summary: The study found low certainty evidence suggesting kiwifruit may increase spontaneous bowel movements compared to psyllium, but results were not definitive. The role of psyllium was not directly evaluated for efficacy or safety in this context.
population_specificity: 399 participants (82% female; mean age 42 years) with constipation.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if preoperative psyllium fiber supplementation reduces the time to first bowel movement after pelvic organ prolapse surgery.
results_summary: The study found no significant difference in time to first bowel movement or pain associated with it between the psyllium and control groups. Psyllium supplementation did not improve postoperative bowel function.
population_specificity: Women undergoing pelvic organ prolapse surgery.
effective_dosage: 3.4 g psyllium fiber twice a day.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of psyllium (7.5 g/day) versus green kiwifruit on gastrointestinal function and comfort in constipated populations.
results_summary: The study found that psyllium was compared to green kiwifruit, which showed clinically relevant increases in complete spontaneous bowel movements and improved GI comfort, but specific efficacy results for psyllium alone were not detailed in the abstract.
population_specificity: Healthy controls (n = 63), patients with functional constipation (n = 60), and patients with constipation-predominant irritable bowel syndrome (n = 61).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effectiveness of fiber supplementation, particularly psyllium, in improving stool output, gut transit time, symptoms, and quality of life in adults with chronic constipation.
results_summary: Psyllium significantly improved stool frequency and consistency, particularly at doses >10 g/d and treatment durations ≥4 weeks, though flatulence was more common in fiber groups compared to controls.
population_specificity: Adults with chronic constipation.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of psyllium on clinical and physiological outcomes in patients with inflammatory bowel disease (IBD).
results_summary: One RCT found no lower remission rates with psyllium treatment, while another reported reduced symptoms in patients. Evidence on psyllium's effectiveness remains limited.
population_specificity: Patients with inflammatory bowel disease (IBD).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether two gold kiwifruit and psyllium daily could effectively manage chronic constipation compared to a placebo.
results_summary: The abstract does not provide specific results regarding psyllium's effects, but the study focused on its use alongside kiwifruit for constipation management.
population_specificity: Adults aged 18-65 years with functional constipation.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the therapeutic effectiveness of biofeedback alone versus biofeedback combined with psyllium or PEG in patients with constipation secondary to pelvic floor dyssynergia.
results_summary: The study found that combining psyllium with biofeedback resulted in a 46.88% satisfaction rate, lower than biofeedback alone (60.83%). Psyllium reduced straining during evacuation but did not significantly improve overall satisfaction or defecation quality compared to biofeedback alone.
population_specificity: 88 patients with constipation secondary to pelvic floor dyssynergia.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy and safety of psyllium as an over-the-counter therapy for chronic constipation.
results_summary: The study found moderate evidence (grade B recommendation) supporting the use of psyllium for chronic constipation, indicating it is effective but with less robust evidence compared to first-line treatments like polyethylene glycol or senna. Common adverse events included diarrhea, nausea, bloating, and abdominal pain, but no serious adverse events were reported.
population_specificity: Individuals with chronic constipation.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether psyllium fiber supplementation reduces diarrhea incidence in enteral tube-fed patients.
results_summary: The study found no difference in diarrheal incidences between fiber-added and fiber-free formulas, indicating psyllium did not significantly reduce diarrhea in this population. The most common cause of diarrhea was medication-associated, not EN-associated or CDAD.
population_specificity: Enteral tube-fed patients

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy of medical treatments, including psyllium powder, for ulcer remission in patients with solitary rectal ulcer syndrome (SRUS).
results_summary: The meta-analysis found that 57% of patients receiving medical treatments (including psyllium) experienced ulcer resolution, though significant heterogeneity was observed. Psyllium was part of the pooled analysis but individual efficacy was not separately reported.
population_specificity: 216 patients (118 males, 98 females) diagnosed with SRUS.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to systematically review the efficacy of prebiotics, including psyllium, in reducing anthropometric and biochemical parameters in individuals with non-alcoholic fatty liver disease (NAFLD).
results_summary: The study found six trials involving psyllium, showing effects on metabolic outcomes in NAFLD patients, including improvements in anthropometric data, liver enzymes, carbohydrate, and lipid parameters. The results suggest psyllium may be beneficial, but the abstract does not provide detailed statistical significance or effect sizes.
population_specificity: Adults aged 38-52 years with non-alcoholic fatty liver disease (NAFLD).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether psyllium supplementation could mitigate licogliflozin-induced stool changes, specifically increased stool frequency and loose stools.
results_summary: Psyllium supplementation (6 g) had no significant effect on stool changes (frequency or consistency) induced by licogliflozin treatment. The study found no improvement in stool outcomes with psyllium compared to no supplementation.
population_specificity: Overweight or obese adults (N=24 per study part).
study_duration: 3 days of licogliflozin treatment with supplementation.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of Psyllium, a poorly fermented natural fiber, in improving functional constipation by targeting gut microbiota composition.
results_summary: The study found that Psyllium significantly improved functional constipation by affecting gut motility and fecal consistency, with efficacy varying based on fiber type and microbiome composition.
population_specificity: Adults and children with functional constipation.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate treatment options, including psyllium, for bowel problems in neurologically impaired children, focusing on constipation and fecal incontinence.
results_summary: The study found that psyllium could be tried in cases of fast colon transit time, but no significant differences between treatment modalities were demonstrated due to small cohort sizes.
population_specificity: Neurologically impaired children, specifically those with cerebral palsy.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effect of psyllium supplementation on symptoms and esophageal function in non-erosive GERD patients with low dietary fiber intake.
results_summary: Psyllium supplementation significantly increased minimal lower esophageal sphincter resting pressure, reduced the number of gastroesophageal reflux episodes, and decreased heartburn frequency per week in NERD patients.
population_specificity: Non-erosive GERD (NERD) patients with low dietary fiber intake (<20 g/d).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if fibre supplementation, including psyllium, is effective in increasing stool frequency, improving stool consistency, and decreasing laxative use in long-term care residents.
results_summary: The study found that added fibre, including psyllium, may increase stool frequency and reduce laxative use in long-term care residents, potentially alleviating constipation. However, more randomized controlled trials are needed to confirm these effects, particularly for insoluble and less fermentable fibre sources.
population_specificity: Long-term care (LTC) residents

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review recent evidence on dietary interventions, including psyllium, for managing irritable bowel syndrome (IBS).
results_summary: The study found insufficient evidence for fibers other than psyllium in IBS, suggesting psyllium may be more effective compared to other fibers. However, the abstract does not provide detailed results on psyllium's specific efficacy.
population_specificity: Patients with irritable bowel syndrome (IBS).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of psyllium versus a delayed, slow-fermenting fiber (SM) on bowel habits, stool consistency, and gut microbiota in individuals with self-described unsatisfactory bowel habits.
results_summary: Psyllium improved stool frequency but not consistency compared to SM. All groups reported similar overall bowel habit improvements, with minimal changes in microbiota and short-chain fatty acids.
population_specificity: 43 healthy volunteers with self-described unsatisfactory bowel habits.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to summarize the physical effects of isolated fibers, including psyllium, in the small and large intestines and their clinically meaningful health benefits.
results_summary: Psyllium's viscosity as a gel-forming fiber drives metabolic health effects like cholesterol lowering and improved glycemic control in the small intestine, while in the large intestine, it resists fermentation and increases water content to soften and bulk stool, providing a laxative effect.
population_specificity: Not specified (general adult population implied).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the role of psyllium as a bulking agent in the management of chronic constipation in diabetic patients.
results_summary: Psyllium was recommended as the first-line bulking agent for managing chronic constipation in diabetic patients, with osmotic laxatives suggested if response is poor. The study highlighted its inclusion in treatment guidelines for improving symptoms and restoring bowel function.
population_specificity: Diabetic patients with chronic constipation.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the safety and efficacy of a polyherbal formulation containing Psyllium for managing dyslipidemia and hyperglycemia in advanced-stage type-2 diabetes patients.
results_summary: The PHF significantly reduced fasting blood glucose, HbA1c, LDL, and triglyceride levels without major adverse effects, though mild nausea and diarrhea were reported in a few patients.
population_specificity: 30 patients with advanced-stage type-2 diabetes, hyperlipidemia, and hyperglycemia despite statin and oral hypoglycemic use.
effective_dosage: One sachet two times daily (exact Psyllium dosage not specified).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the efficacy of polyethylene glycol (PEG) with other laxatives, including psyllium, in treating functional constipation and fecal impaction.
results_summary: The study included one clinical trial comparing PEG with psyllium, but no specific results regarding psyllium's efficacy or safety were detailed in the abstract.
population_specificity: Adults and pediatric patients with functional constipation or fecal impaction.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of psyllium in ameliorating symptoms of irritable bowel syndrome (IBS).
results_summary: The study found that psyllium appears effective in improving IBS symptoms, though the overall evidence is limited by small sample sizes and poor methodological quality in available studies.
population_specificity: Patients with irritable bowel syndrome (IBS).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess whether dietary fibres like psyllium could offer an efficient treatment for IBD patients by modulating the gut microbiota and reducing inflammation.
results_summary: The abstract suggests that dietary fibres, including psyllium, may have beneficial outcomes for IBD by altering the microbiome and producing short-chain fatty acids, potentially reducing disease progression and colorectal cancer risk.
population_specificity: Patients with inflammatory bowel disease (IBD).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the physical characteristics of fibers, including psyllium, that exert a laxative effect and their clinical evidence in treating constipation.
results_summary: Psyllium, as a non-fermented, gel-forming soluble fiber, retains its gelled nature and high water-holding capacity throughout the large bowel, resulting in soft, bulky, and easy-to-pass stools, demonstrating a significant laxative effect.
population_specificity: Not specified (general population with constipation, inferred from context).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the efficacy and tolerability of a mixed soluble/insoluble fibre supplement versus psyllium in treating constipation.
results_summary: Psyllium significantly increased complete spontaneous bowel movements and improved stool consistency, straining, bloating, and quality of life, with no significant difference compared to mixed fibre. However, mixed fibre was more effective in relieving flatulence and dissolved better.
population_specificity: Constipated patients meeting Rome III criteria.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of psyllium supplementation on satiety, hunger, and desire to eat between meals in two sequential clinical trials.
results_summary: Both studies showed that psyllium significantly reduced hunger and desire to eat while increasing fullness between meals, with the 6.8 g dose providing the most consistent benefits. Adverse events were mild and similar to placebo, primarily consisting of gastrointestinal symptoms.
population_specificity: Individuals seeking to control hunger between meals (specific demographics not detailed).
effective_dosage: 3.4 g, 6.8 g, and 10.2 g taken before breakfast and lunch (Study 1); 6.8 g taken before breakfast and lunch on Days 1-2 and before breakfast on Day 3 (Study 2).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the health impacts of breakfast cereals, including psyllium-based cereals, on cholesterol levels and overall nutrition.
results_summary: Psyllium-based cereals were found to help lower cholesterol concentrations (grade A evidence). The study also noted that high-fiber cereals, including those with psyllium, improve bowel function (grade A evidence).
population_specificity: General population, with no specific subgroup mentioned for psyllium.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the efficacy and safety of PEG-based laxatives, including psyllium fiber, for treating chronic constipation and fecal impaction in children.
results_summary: The meta-analysis found that PEG-based laxatives were more effective for disimpaction compared to non-PEG laxatives like psyllium, with acceptable adverse events. Psyllium's specific efficacy was not highlighted as superior to PEG.
population_specificity: Children with functional constipation or fecal impaction.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the potential benefits of Psyllium as a prebiotic in patients with active ulcerative colitis or ulcerative colitis in remission.
results_summary: The study suggests that Psyllium, among other prebiotics, might provide some benefit for patients with active ulcerative colitis or those in remission, though the evidence is not as strong as for certain probiotics like VSL#3.
population_specificity: Patients with active ulcerative colitis or ulcerative colitis in remission.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the evidence supporting psyllium's effectiveness in managing specific symptoms of irritable bowel syndrome (IBS).
results_summary: The study found that psyllium is among the medications with demonstrated improvements for IBS symptoms, supported by reliable evidence, though the onset of efficacy and long-term effects were not prospectively assessed at predefined periods.
population_specificity: Patients with irritable bowel syndrome (IBS).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of psyllium, a dietary fiber supplement, with other fibers and a placebo in reducing fecal incontinence frequency and improving related outcomes.
results_summary: Psyllium significantly decreased fecal incontinence frequency compared to placebo, with estimated episodes/week dropping from 5.5 (placebo) to 2.5 (psyllium). It also formed a gel in feces, which appeared to be a key mechanism for its effectiveness.
population_specificity: Community-living individuals with incontinence of loose/liquid feces.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effect of dietary fiber, including psyllium, on constipation by analyzing randomized controlled trials.
results_summary: Dietary fiber, including psyllium, significantly increased stool frequency in constipated patients but did not significantly improve stool consistency, treatment success, laxative use, or painful defecation.
population_specificity: Patients with constipation

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the fermentation extent of psyllium (PSY) with other fibers (gum arabic and carboxymethylcellulose) and assess whether prior fiber consumption influenced bacterial degradation.
results_summary: Psyllium showed intermediate fermentation compared to gum arabic (higher) and carboxymethylcellulose (lower). Prior consumption of a specific fiber did not enhance its degradation, suggesting rapid bacterial adaptation to new fiber substrates.
population_specificity: Nonadapted human bacterial population from three normal subjects and 52 subjects with fecal incontinence.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the effect of psyllium on postprandial glycaemia and in vitro digestibility in extruded snack foods.
results_summary: Psyllium significantly reduced both in vitro and in vivo glycaemic responses compared to a control snack. Oat bran reduced in vitro starch digestibility but did not affect in vivo glycaemic response, though it appeared to prolong glucose release.
population_specificity: Not specified (general population consuming extruded snack foods).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of a conservative treatment algorithm, including psyllium, for patients with faecal soiling and normal sphincter function.
results_summary: Psyllium treatment significantly reduced faecal soiling frequency, the need for daily pads, and improved Vaizey incontinence scores (P < 0.001). Complete resolution of soiling occurred in 24% of patients after psyllium treatment.
population_specificity: 50 patients (41 men, 9 women; mean age 38) with faecal soiling and normal anorectal function.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the lipid-lowering effects of psyllium (medium-viscosity) against low-viscosity wheat bran and a high-viscosity fibre blend in healthy individuals consuming a typical North American diet.
results_summary: Psyllium (medium-viscosity) showed a significant but lesser LDL-C reduction compared to the high-viscosity fibre blend, with a positive association between fibre viscosity and LDL-C reduction observed. Despite lower intake, high-viscosity fibres were more effective.
population_specificity: Apparently healthy individuals (12 males, 11 females; mean age 35 years) consuming a typical North American diet.
study_duration: 3 weeks per intervention, separated by ≥2-week washout periods

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the potential of Psyllium and other herbal preparations in treating radiotherapy-induced dysuria based on Iranian Traditional Medicine.
results_summary: The study suggests that Psyllium and other mucilaginous herbs may be effective for dysuria due to their anti-inflammatory, anti-oxidant, and tissue-regenerative properties, but acknowledges the lack of sufficient clinical trials to confirm outcomes.
population_specificity: Patients undergoing pelvic radiotherapy (e.g., for prostate, rectal, or uterine cervix cancer).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy of Psyllium and other medications in treating IBS symptoms, including secondary endpoints, based on IBS subtypes.
results_summary: The study found that Psyllium, among other fiber supplements, showed improvement in various IBS symptoms, though the evidence is limited and more well-designed studies are needed.
population_specificity: Patients with irritable bowel syndrome (IBS), categorized by subtype.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the effectiveness of laxatives, including Psyllium, for treating chronic constipation in elderly patients.
results_summary: The study found that Psyllium resulted in a mean stool frequency of 9.08 bowel movements per week, which was statistically significant compared to calcium polycarbophil (8.29 per week, P = 0.04). However, the abstract does not provide detailed efficacy comparisons with other laxatives beyond frequency.
population_specificity: Elderly patients (mean age ≥65 years) with chronic constipation.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of dietary fiber from a healthy diet versus psyllium supplementation, or a combination of both, on metabolic syndrome risk factors in overweight and obese individuals.
results_summary: Psyllium supplementation alone significantly improved weight, BMI, body fat, cholesterol, and LDL-cholesterol. Combining psyllium with a healthy diet provided the greatest improvements in metabolic syndrome risk factors, including reductions in triglycerides and insulin.
population_specificity: Overweight and obese adults
effective_dosage: Not specified (fiber intake increased to 55 g in the FIB group)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of baked psyllium supplementation versus a placebo on constipation symptoms, body weight, glycemic control, and lipid levels in patients with type 2 diabetes (T2D) and chronic constipation.
results_summary: Psyllium supplementation significantly improved constipation symptoms, reduced body weight, lowered fasting plasma glucose (FPG), HbA1c, cholesterol, and triglycerides, and increased HDL-C levels compared to the placebo group. Compliance was good, and no adverse effects were reported.
population_specificity: 51 patients with T2D and chronic constipation, BMI 20-47 kg/m².

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the benefits of psyllium supplementation on metabolic syndrome components, including glucose levels, insulin response, blood pressure, lipid profile, and appetite control.
results_summary: Psyllium supplementation improved glucose levels, insulin response, blood pressure, and lipid profile in both animals and humans, reducing metabolic risk factors. It also decreased appetite in most studies, suggesting potential benefits for weight and body composition management.
population_specificity: Animals and humans with metabolic syndrome risk factors (e.g., hypercholesterolaemia, hypertriglyceridaemia, hyperglycaemia).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether Pterostilbene could protect against oxidative stress and slow the progression of diabetic retinopathy in patients.
results_summary: Pterostilbene reduced retinal vascular alterations and oxidative damage markers (e.g., lipid peroxidation) in diabetic retinopathy patients, with benefits disappearing after treatment cessation. It also improved the GSH/GSSG ratio, indicating restored redox balance.
population_specificity: Patients with diabetic retinopathy
study_duration: Not specified (follow-up at six months post-treatment)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to systematically review and summarize the potential therapeutic effects of Pterostilbene (PTS) on Alzheimer's disease (AD) through various mechanisms.
results_summary: PTS demonstrated potential therapeutic effects on AD through multiple mechanisms, including anti-oxidative damage, anti-neuroinflammation, anti-apoptosis, cholinesterase inhibition, and attenuation of β-amyloid deposition and tau protein hyperphosphorylation. Molecular docking and network pharmacology analyses indicated strong binding affinity and multiple potential mechanisms of action for PTS in AD.
population_specificity: Not specified (in vivo and in vitro studies reviewed).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore whether pterostilbene enhances neuron-like differentiation in PC12 cells by potentiating the functions of nerve growth factor (NGF).
results_summary: Pterostilbene significantly enhanced NGF-induced neurite extension and neurofilament expression in PC12 cells by activating the TrkA/Akt/CREB signaling pathway. The combined treatment of pterostilbene with a low dose of NGF showed greater efficacy than NGF alone.
population_specificity: PC12 cells (a model for neuronal differentiation)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the antiproliferative effect of pterostilbene (PT) combined with megestrol acetate (MA) versus MA alone in preoperative treatment of endometrial cancer (EC).
results_summary: PT+MA showed no significant difference in Ki-67 changes overall but demonstrated a greater relative decrease in Ki67 (33.8% vs. 20.1%) in the endometroid subtype. Transcriptomic analysis revealed activation of interferon alpha response and suppression of mTORC1 signaling, hypoxia, and oxidative phosphorylation.
population_specificity: 44 patients with endometrial cancer (23 in PT+MA arm, 21 in MA arm).
study_duration: Three weeks prior to scheduled hysterectomy.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of pterostilbene on intestinal barrier damage and secondary liver oxidative stress induced by Clostridium difficile infection (CDI) in mice, as well as its impact on gut microbiota and bile acid profiles.
results_summary: Pterostilbene reduced harmful bacteria (e.g., Enterococcus) and increased beneficial bacteria (e.g., Lactobacillus), reshaped gut microbiota and bile acid profiles, activated intestinal FXR signaling, alleviated colonic inflammation, and reduced liver oxidative stress. It also reduced intestinal permeability, preventing bacterial toxin translocation to the liver.
population_specificity: Mice with Clostridium difficile infection (CDI).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate Pterostilbene's cytotoxicity and apoptosis-inducing effects in bladder cancer cells compared to normal bladder epithelial cells.
results_summary: Pterostilbene induced significant apoptosis in bladder cancer HTB-9 cells in a dose- and time-dependent manner, with minimal effects on normal SV-HUC-1 cells. Apoptotic protein expression, particularly caspase-3, was positively correlated with treatment.
population_specificity: Bladder cancer HTB-9 cells and normal bladder epithelial SV-HUC-1 cells (in vitro study).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether Pterostilbene (PTE) protects against cerebral ischemia-reperfusion injury (CIRI) by modulating the Wnt/β-catenin pathway and reducing ferroptosis.
results_summary: PTE treatment activated the Wnt/β-catenin pathway, reduced ferroptosis markers (iron ions, lipid peroxides), and improved neuronal damage in both in vitro and in vivo models of CIRI. It also countered the detrimental effects of ferroptosis activators and Wnt pathway inhibitors.
population_specificity: Mouse hippocampal neuron (HT22) cells and in vivo mouse models of CIRI.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to identify molecular targets and pathways modulated by pterostilbene in breast cancer and assess its potential as a treatment option.
results_summary: Pterostilbene showed robust binding to key nuclear receptors (PTGS2, ESR1, EGFR, BCL2), selective cytotoxicity in MCF-7 breast cancer cells (IC50 = 14.8 µM), and low toxicity risk, suggesting potential modulation of estrogen receptor signaling.
population_specificity: MCF-7 breast cancer cells and normal HEL 299 cells (in vitro).
study_duration: Molecular dynamics simulations over 200 ns; in vitro assay duration not specified.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether pterostilbene exerts neuroprotective effects on neuronal-like cells with induced cell cycle reactivation and alters DNA methylation patterns.
results_summary: Pterostilbene showed neuroprotective benefits in differentiated neuronal-like cells but not in cells undergoing induced division. It also altered DNA methylation patterns.
population_specificity: Neuronal-like cells derived from the human neuroblastoma SK-N-BE cell line.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the molecular mechanisms by which pterostilbene protects bovine spermatozoa from oxidative stress during freezing/thawing.
results_summary: Pterostilbene reduced lipid peroxidation, increased intracellular GSH levels, restored ATP and AMP/ATP levels, activated AMPK to enhance autophagy, and inhibited apoptotic cell death in bovine spermatozoa exposed to oxidative stress. These effects were dose-independent.
population_specificity: Bovine spermatozoa

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether Pterostilbene (PTS) could counteract cisplatin resistance in gastric cancer (GC) cells and explore its pharmacological mechanisms.
results_summary: PTS inhibited cell viability and confluence, promoted apoptosis via increased caspase-9/-3 activity, and induced autophagy in cisplatin-resistant GC cells. RNA-Seq analysis revealed PTS reduced expression of key genes (ATM/ATR, HIF-1, PI3K, etc.) linked to apoptosis and autophagy.
population_specificity: Cisplatin-resistant gastric cancer cells (in vitro).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of whey protein isolate-tannic acid conjugates for encapsulating pterostilbene to enhance its intestinal-targeted delivery and functional properties.
results_summary: The study found that laccase-induced WPI-TA conjugates had the highest grafting efficiency, improved thermal stability, antioxidant properties, and sustained release of pterostilbene in the gastrointestinal tract, with water solubility 361.19 times higher than free pterostilbene.
population_specificity: Not specified (in vitro or ex vivo study implied).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the cytotoxic, antiproliferative, proapoptotic, and antimigrative effects of Pterostilbene (PS) on head and neck cancer (HNC) cell lines.
results_summary: PS demonstrated dose-dependent cytotoxic and antiproliferative activity in HNC cells by modulating apoptotic genes (upregulating CASP-3 and BAX, downregulating BCL-2) and significantly suppressing cell migration. Proapoptotic effects were confirmed via annexin-V-PI staining.
population_specificity: HEp-2, SCC-90, SCC-9, FaDu, and Detroit-551 cell lines (in vitro study).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether Pterostilbene (PTS) is metabolized by tyrosinase similarly to resveratrol (RES) and to assess its cytotoxicity and melanin-inhibiting effects in melanoma cells.
results_summary: PTS was oxidized by tyrosinase to form a cytotoxic o-quinone metabolite, showed higher uptake and metabolism in human cells compared to RES, and demonstrated stronger tyrosinase-dependent cytotoxicity and melanin inhibition in melanoma cells.
population_specificity: Human tyrosinase-expressing 293T cells and B16BL6 melanoma cells.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether pterostilbene could protect retinal function and structure in rats subjected to retinal ischemia-reperfusion (I/R) injury.
results_summary: Pterostilbene significantly improved retinal function (increased b-wave amplitude), reduced retinal thinning, and decreased expression of pro-apoptotic and inflammatory markers (GFAP, HSP70, PARP1, NFκB). These findings suggest pterostilbene mitigates oxidative stress, inflammation, and apoptosis in retinal I/R injury.
population_specificity: Male Sprague Dawley rats with induced retinal I/R injury.
study_duration: One week of reperfusion with treatment

study_goal: The researchers aimed to summarize current research on pterostilbene, focusing on its potential therapeutic role in treating cardiovascular disease.
results_summary: The study highlights pterostilbene's anti-inflammatory and antioxidant effects, high bioavailability, and low toxicity, suggesting its promise for cardiovascular health. However, specific clinical outcomes or statistical results are not detailed in the abstract.
population_specificity: Not specified (general research on pterostilbene's effects).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of free pterostilbene (PTB) and PLGA nanoparticles loaded with PTB on tomato plant metabolism, focusing on primary and secondary metabolites, fatty acids, oxylipins, and hormones.
results_summary: Both free PTB and PLGA NPs loaded with PTB increased GABA levels and shifted secondary metabolism toward phenylpropanoid biosynthesis. The treatments also modulated fatty acid and oxylipin metabolism, suggesting a role in plant redox modulation and stress response.
population_specificity: Solanum lycopersicum L. (tomato plants)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether Pterostilbene (PTE) could mitigate oxidative stress and neuronal apoptosis following intracerebral hemorrhage (ICH) and elucidate the underlying pathways, particularly the SIRT1/Nrf2 pathway.
results_summary: PTE reduced oxidative stress and neuronal apoptosis in mice with ICH, activating the SIRT1/Nrf2 pathway. Inhibition of SIRT1 negated these protective effects, suggesting PTE's benefits are mediated through this pathway.
population_specificity: Male C57BL/6 mice with induced ICH.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the role of Pterostilbene (PTS) in regulating Nrf1 and its potential therapeutic effects on neuroinflammation and microglial activation in models of ischaemic stroke.
results_summary: PTS reduced HDAC3 expression and activity, increased Nrf1 acetylation, and decreased neuroinflammation and infarct volume in ischaemic stroke models. The therapeutic effects of PTS were dependent on Nrf1 acetylation and were attenuated by microglial elimination.
population_specificity: Mouse model of middle cerebral artery occlusion-reperfusion (MCAO/R) and microglial oxygen-glucose deprivation/reperfusion (OGD/R) model.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to develop and evaluate aqueous core nanocapsules (ACNs) containing pterostilbene (PTE) and resveratrol (RSV) for prostate cancer treatment, focusing on synergistic effects and improved drug delivery.
results_summary: The study found that a 1:1 ratio of PTE and RSV in ACNs showed high synergy, improved encapsulation (72% for PTE), stability, no systemic toxicity, and effective biodistribution in prostate cells. The formulation also demonstrated prolonged half-life and reduced clearance, indicating high effectiveness for prostate cancer.
population_specificity: Prostate cancer cells (PC-3 cell line) and in vivo models (specifics not detailed).
effective_dosage: Not specified (molar ratio 1:1 of PTE and RSV used).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether pterostilbene (PTS) could improve insulin resistance, hormonal profiles, and cognitive deficits in a PCOS rat model, comparing its effects to metformin (MET).
results_summary: PTS improved insulin sensitivity, hormonal balance, cognitive performance, and brain histopathology in PCOS rats, likely by modulating the IRS-1/PI3K/AKT/GSK-3β pathway and reducing inflammation. Its effects were comparable to MET in most parameters.
population_specificity: Female rats with letrozole-induced PCOS.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to identify potential biomarkers for lung squamous cell carcinoma (LUSC) and explore how pterostilbene (PT) interacts with these biomarkers during LUSC treatment.
results_summary: PT suppressed cell viability, induced apoptosis, and inhibited migration and invasion in LUSC cell lines by downregulating KANK3. Reinduction of KANK3 impaired PT's anti-LUSC effects, suggesting PT works in a KANK3-dependent manner.
population_specificity: Lung squamous cell carcinoma (LUSC) patients and LUSC cell lines.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of pterostilbene (PTE) supplementation on immune function, inflammation, antioxidant status, and intestinal health in broilers.
results_summary: PTE supplementation at 400 mg/kg significantly improved immune function, reduced inflammation, enhanced antioxidant capacity, and improved intestinal morphology in broilers. It increased beneficial serum markers and antioxidant enzymes while reducing inflammatory cytokines and oxidative stress markers.
population_specificity: 1-day-old Arbor Acres broilers (480 birds divided into four groups).
effective_dosage: 200, 400, or 600 mg/kg of PTE in feed.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate whether dietary pterostilbene (PSB) could protect against high-fat-diet-induced hepatic lipid accumulation exacerbated by chronic jet lag and explore the role of gut microbiota in this process.
results_summary: PSB supplementation significantly mitigated obesity and hepatic lipid accumulation caused by chronic jet lag and a high-fat diet by promoting hepatic lipolysis and β-oxidation via SIRT1 upregulation. It also reduced oxidative stress and prevented excessive autophagy and mitochondrial fission through SIRT1 and SIRT3 activation, with gut microbiota modulation contributing to these benefits.
population_specificity: Mice on a high-fat diet subjected to chronic jet lag

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate whether pterostilbene (Pt) could inhibit STING signaling and prevent abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA) formation in a mouse model.
results_summary: Pt effectively blocked AAA formation in AngII-infused ApoE-/- mice by activating the KEAP1/Nrf2 pathway, which suppressed STING signaling, reduced inflammation, and preserved vascular smooth muscle cell function. VSMC-specific Nrf2 knockdown largely negated Pt's protective effects.
population_specificity: Angiotensin II-infused apolipoprotein E-deficient (ApoE-/-) mice.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to identify potential targets and mechanisms underlying Pterostilbene's anticancer effects in cervical cancer to support its future clinical application.
results_summary: The study identified 36 overlapping targets between Pterostilbene and cervical cancer, with 9 core targets (e.g., IL1B, EGFR, JUN) primarily enriched in MAPK and IL-17 signaling pathways. Molecular docking confirmed PTE's binding to these targets, with MMP1-PTE showing the most stable interaction, suggesting a potential mechanism for its anticancer activity.
population_specificity: Preclinical study focusing on cervical cancer mechanisms (no human subjects).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the therapeutic potential of Pterostilbene (PTS) in liver cancer by analyzing its interactions with key proteins in the Wnt signaling pathway using computational methods.
results_summary: Molecular docking showed strong binding affinities between PTS and Wnt-related proteins, with notable hydrogen bonds and hydrophobic interactions. ADME studies indicated favorable pharmacokinetic properties, including moderate solubility and low drug interaction risk.
population_specificity: Computational study (no human or animal subjects).
interactions: Minimal chance of drug interactions noted.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the protective effects and safety of pterostilbene (PT) for osteoarthritis (OA) in a mouse model and in vitro experiments.
results_summary: PT alleviated chondrocyte loss and joint space narrowing in OA mice, reduced NLRP3 inflammation activation and inflammatory cytokine release via NF-κB signaling inactivation, and improved gut microbiota by reducing inflammation-associated bacteria and increasing healthy bacteria.
population_specificity: OCP-induced OA mouse model (n = 3) and in vitro experiments.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effect of Pterostilbene (PTE) on oxidative stress in animal models of myocardial infarction (MI) and pulmonary arterial hypertension (PAH).
results_summary: PTE administration attenuated the decrease in ejection fraction and improved left ventricle end-systolic volume in infarcted animals, while in the PAH model, PTE improved pulmonary artery flow and reduced reactive oxygen species levels in the lung. PTE demonstrated protective effects against oxidative stress in both disease models.
population_specificity: Male Wistar rats with induced MI or PAH.
study_duration: 8 days for MI model, 14 days for PAH model.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to enhance the therapeutic potential of pterostilbene (PTE) by developing a nanomedicine solution that improves its bioavailability and targeted delivery to cancer cells.
results_summary: The aptamer-PTE conjugate demonstrated superior cytotoxicity in cancer cells compared to free PTE and effectively inhibited tumor growth and neovascularization in a zebrafish xenograft model.
population_specificity: Cancer cells and zebrafish xenograft model

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the efficacy and potential mechanism of Pterostilbene (PTE) in treating gastric cancer (GC), focusing on its effects on proliferation, metastasis, and the JAK2/STAT3 pathway.
results_summary: PTE demonstrated strong inhibitory effects on GC cells in vitro and in vivo, including cell cycle arrest, reduced proliferation, migration, and invasion, as well as tumor volume reduction. It also suppressed the JAK2/STAT3 pathway and EMT-associated proteins, with safety confirmed in mice.
population_specificity: Gastric cancer cells (in vitro) and xenograft tumor models (in vivo).

study_goal: The researchers were reviewing the clinical characteristics, diagnostic criteria, differential diagnoses, and therapeutic management of CLIPPERS, not studying salt.
results_summary: The abstract does not discuss salt or its effects; it focuses on CLIPPERS, its diagnosis, and treatment.
population_specificity: Middle-aged patients with subacute onset of pontocerebellar symptoms and characteristic MRI findings.

study_goal: The researchers were examining the potential of polymeric hydrogels as vitreous substitutes in ocular diseases, not evaluating Salt.
results_summary: The study did not investigate Salt; it focused on hydrogels for vitreous replacement, highlighting their advantages over current substitutes like air, gas, and silicone oil.
population_specificity: Patients with ocular diseases (e.g., retinal detachment, diabetic retinopathy).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the history and current evidence for diuretic strategies in treating fluid retention in heart failure patients and explore future research directions.
results_summary: The abstract highlights a lack of robust data on diuretic therapy in clinical practice, with the strongest evidence supporting high-dose loop diuretics for hospitalized heart failure patients, though this is not reflected in guidelines. It calls for more research on different diuretic strategies.
population_specificity: Patients with heart failure (HF) experiencing fluid retention or congestion.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review congenital adrenal hyperplasia (CAH) due to 21-hydroxylase deficiency, including its presentations, diagnosis, and treatment, with a mention of salt replacement as part of therapy.
results_summary: The study found that mineralocorticoid and salt replacement may be necessary for treating CAH, but it did not specifically evaluate the efficacy or safety of salt itself.
population_specificity: Children and adolescents with congenital adrenal hyperplasia (CAH).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review advancements in bacterial laccases for bioremediation and wastewater treatment, focusing on their potential to degrade xenobiotic compounds in high-salt and extreme pH environments.
results_summary: The study found that laccases show promise in degrading xenobiotic compounds in wastewater but face challenges due to high salt concentrations and extreme pH, which affect enzyme stability and recovery. Genetic and protein engineering, along with improved production processes, are suggested to enhance their efficacy.
population_specificity: Not specified (focus on bacterial laccases and their applications in wastewater treatment).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy of combining fractional carbon dioxide laser with topical bimatoprost solution for treating alopecia areata compared to monotherapy.
results_summary: The combination therapy showed significantly greater improvement in SALT scores (46.43% vs. 21.16%) compared to monotherapy, with sustained benefits at follow-up. The results were statistically significant (p = 0.000).
population_specificity: 20 patients with alopecia areata.

study_goal: The study aimed to determine the prevalence of HLA-B27 in patients with ankylosing spondylitis (AS) in Diyarbakır and investigate its relationship with disease severity and genetic associations.
results_summary: The study found a 92% prevalence of HLA-B27 in AS patients in Diyarbakır, higher than the national average, but did not assess the effects of salt.
population_specificity: 198 AS patients (104 male, 94 female) and 50 healthy controls (25 male, 25 female) in Diyarbakır, Turkey.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether high dietary salt intake elevates circulating IL-17A in women with preeclampsia compared to healthy pregnant and non-pregnant women, and whether salt intake affects cytokine levels.
results_summary: The study found that high salt intake did not affect blood pressure or plasma cytokine concentrations in any group. Preeclampsia was associated with elevated levels of TNF and IL-6, but IL-17A and related cytokines were not sensitive to salt intake.
population_specificity: Non-pregnant women (n=13), healthy pregnant women (n=15), and women with preeclampsia (n=7).
effective_dosage: Low sodium diet (50-60 mmol NaCl/24h) for 10 days, followed by placebo tablets (low salt) or salt tablets (172 mmol NaCl/24h, high salt) for 5+5 days.
study_duration: 10 days of low sodium diet, followed by 10 days of intervention (5 days low salt, 5 days high salt).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the efficacy of Janus kinase (JAK) inhibitors and biologics in treating alopecia areata (AA) using the Severity of Alopecia Tool (SALT).
results_summary: The study conducted a systematic review and meta-analysis of randomized trials reporting SALT outcomes but did not specify results regarding Salt (sodium chloride).
population_specificity: Patients with alopecia areata (AA).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review advancements in the diagnosis and treatment of adrenal insufficiency (AI), including symptoms like salt craving in primary AI.
results_summary: The abstract highlights that salt craving is a clinical feature of primary AI but does not provide specific results on salt's effects or efficacy.
population_specificity: Individuals with adrenal insufficiency, particularly those with primary AI.

study_goal: The researchers sought to evaluate the incorporation of potassium-enriched salt substitutes into clinical guidelines for hypertension and chronic kidney disease management.
results_summary: The study found that potassium-enriched, sodium-reduced salt substitutes effectively improve consumption levels, reduce blood pressure, and lower cardiovascular event rates, but their use is inconsistently recommended in clinical guidelines.
population_specificity: Patients with hypertension, excluding those with advanced kidney disease, using potassium supplements, or taking potassium-sparing diuretics.
effective_dosage: Composition of 75% sodium chloride and 25% potassium chloride.
interactions: Contraindicated with potassium supplements, potassium-sparing diuretics, and advanced kidney disease.

study_goal: The researchers sought to analyze biomaterial approaches for targeted delivery of plasma-activated species, including their behavior in salt solutions, to enhance therapeutic potential.
results_summary: The abstract does not provide specific findings about Salt's effects but highlights the potential of plasma-activated species in biomedical applications, including their interaction with salt solutions.
population_specificity: Not specified (review article, no specific population studied).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to analyze the physical and chemical properties of natural mud from salt lakes in Kazakhstan and assess its therapeutic potential.
results_summary: The study found that natural mud from Kazakh salt lakes has therapeutic effects on the skin with fewer side effects, but research is incomplete, particularly regarding organic matter and regions like Northern and Eastern Kazakhstan.
population_specificity: Not specified (focus on natural mud sources in Kazakhstan).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the therapeutic potential of modulating bile salt homeostasis in treating cholestatic liver diseases.
results_summary: The study found that inhibiting bile salt transporters (ASBT, NTCP) and FXR agonism showed effectiveness against cholestatic liver diseases, while UDCA and norUDCA demonstrated therapeutic promise. Altered bile salt compositions and T-cell responses were implicated in disease pathogenesis.
population_specificity: Patients with cholestatic liver diseases (e.g., primary biliary cholangitis, primary sclerosing cholangitis, intrahepatic cholestasis of pregnancy).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess heart failure patients' awareness of salt intake and its role in disease management, as well as their compliance with dietary recommendations.
results_summary: The study found that 73.3% of heart failure patients reported paying attention to their salt intake, with 33.5% following a completely salt-free diet, indicating moderate awareness but room for improvement in dietary adherence.
population_specificity: Heart failure patients (mean age 59.8 ± 14.9 years) diagnosed for at least 6 months from 10 cardiology clinics.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the feasibility and acceptability of using the SwapSHOP app to encourage healthier grocery purchases, including reducing salt intake.
results_summary: The study found insufficient data to analyze salt reduction due to low participant numbers in the salt group (n=5 intervention, n=1 control). No significant results were reported for salt.
population_specificity: Adult volunteers in the United Kingdom, focusing on those concerned with salt intake.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the management of complicating conditions (diabetes mellitus, polycystic kidney disease, and chronic liver disease) in patients undergoing peritoneal dialysis (PD), focusing on the effects of PD on these conditions and vice versa.
results_summary: The study found that glucose absorption from PD dialysate complicates metabolic control in diabetes, affecting salt and water management. PD may be a better option than hemodialysis for liver disease patients with complications like low BP or ascites, though mortality remains high.
population_specificity: Patients with complicating conditions (diabetes mellitus, polycystic kidney disease, chronic liver disease) undergoing peritoneal dialysis.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the impact of salt and water intake on the progression of chronic kidney disease (CKD) and determine optimal consumption levels to preserve glomerular filtration rate.
results_summary: Sodium intake shows a complex J-shaped association with CKD progression, with low-sodium diets demonstrating promise in reducing blood pressure and enhancing the effects of certain medications, though their independent impact on CKD progression remains debated. The role of water consumption in CKD is uncertain, requiring further research.
population_specificity: Non-dialysis chronic kidney disease (CKD) patients.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the efficacy of mineralocorticoid receptor antagonists (MRA) in treating low-renin hypertension (LRH), a condition linked to excess salt and volume expansion.
results_summary: The meta-analysis found that MRA reduced systolic blood pressure by -6.8 mmHg compared to ACEi/ARB and -4.8 mmHg compared to diuretics, with moderate to very low certainty of evidence, suggesting MRA may be more effective than ACEi/ARB for LRH.
population_specificity: Adults with low-renin hypertension (n = 1043 across 17 studies).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the implications of variations in norepinephrine formulations (labeled as conjugated salt or base drug) and provide guidance for clinical practice, research, and patient safety.
results_summary: The study found significant implications for clinical care, dose calculations in trials, and dataset reporting due to norepinephrine formulation variations, advocating for a uniform norepinephrine-base formulation globally.
population_specificity: Multinational and multidisciplinary critical care experts assembled by the Society of Critical Care Medicine and the European Society of Intensive Care Medicine.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate whether current dialysis guidelines, including dietary restrictions on salt, are appropriate for older patients with different physiological needs.
results_summary: The study suggests that older dialysis patients may benefit from liberalized dietary salt restrictions to prevent malnutrition, as their lower metabolic activity and reduced appetite differ from younger patients.
population_specificity: Elderly patients (>75 years) initiating dialysis, particularly those with residual kidney function and lower metabolic activity.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the role of the epithelial sodium channel (ENaC) in salt sensitivity of blood pressure (SSBP) and its link to inflammation and cardiovascular risk.
results_summary: The study found that sodium entry via ENaC in dendritic cells triggers inflammation, leading to the production of isolevuglandins (IsoLGs), which promote T-cell activation, cytokine release, and kidney damage in SSBP. A novel pathway involving ENaC and IsoLG-dependent NLRP3 inflammasome activation was also identified.
population_specificity: Not specified (mechanistic study, likely preclinical or in vitro).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review factors driving vascular inflammation and hypertension, with emphasis on the role of salt and reactive oxygen species in vascular smooth muscle cell dysfunction.
results_summary: The abstract indicates that salt, among other proinflammatory factors, enhances vascular smooth muscle cell contractility and impairs relaxation, contributing to oxidative stress and vascular aging. The study highlights the role of Nox1 NADPH oxidase in generating reactive oxygen species that exacerbate these effects.
population_specificity: Not specified (general vascular physiology focus)

study_goal: The researchers were examining the management of cirrhosis, including salt restriction as part of ascites treatment.
results_summary: The abstract mentions salt restriction as a simple intervention for managing ascites in cirrhosis, but no specific results regarding its effectiveness are provided.
population_specificity: Patients with cirrhosis, particularly in resource-constrained settings like sub-Saharan Africa.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of behavioral interventions focused on salt reduction on blood pressure and urinary sodium excretion.
results_summary: Behavioral interventions significantly reduced systolic blood pressure (-1.17 mmHg), diastolic blood pressure (-0.58 mmHg), and urinary sodium excretion (-21.88 mmol/24 hours), suggesting effectiveness in lowering salt intake and blood pressure.
population_specificity: 4,667 participants (3,796 adults and 871 children)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the role of immune activation, including the impact of a high-salt environment, in the initiation and progression of hypertension.
results_summary: The study found that a high-salt environment contributes to immune activation in hypertension, leading to elevated blood pressure and damage to target organs such as arteries, kidneys, heart, and brain. Immune cells and cytokines, including IL-17, were implicated in these adverse effects.
population_specificity: Individuals with hypertension (global population, >1.3 billion affected).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to summarize how chronic liver diseases alter drug pharmacokinetics and pharmacodynamics, focusing on metabolic enzyme and transport protein changes.
results_summary: The study found decreased expression/activity of cytochrome P450 enzymes (e.g., CYP2E1, CYP3A4) and transporters (e.g., OATP1B1, bile salt export pump) in liver disease patients, leading to altered drug absorption, metabolism, and potential drug-drug interactions.
population_specificity: Patients with chronic liver diseases (e.g., type 2 diabetes, metabolic dysfunction-associated steatotic liver disease, cirrhosis).
interactions: Altered drug pharmacokinetics may lead to specific drug-drug interactions in liver disease patients.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the efficacy of an mHealth app-based intervention in supporting self-management of hypertension, including promoting low-salt diets, among patients in a high-salt diet region.
results_summary: The mHealth intervention significantly improved blood pressure control, hypertension knowledge, and lifestyle behaviors, including low salt intake, compared to usual care. The intervention group showed greater reductions in systolic and diastolic blood pressure and better adherence to healthy behaviors.
population_specificity: 297 patients with hypertension at the General Hospital of Ningxia Medical University, Ningxia Hui Autonomous Region, China.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the renal effects of GLP-1 and its potential role in renoprotection, particularly in relation to salt sensitivity and insulin resistance.
results_summary: The study found that GLP-1 has a natriuretic effect during volume expansion, associated with high renal extraction of GLP-1, suppression of angiotensin II, and increased medullary and cortical perfusion, suggesting a functional GLP-1 kidney axis in humans.
population_specificity: Human subjects in randomized, controlled mechanistic studies (specific demographics not detailed).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of dietary sodium restriction and the use of a low-sodium salt substitute on blood pressure and cardiovascular disease risk.
results_summary: The study found that reducing dietary sodium intake from approximately 5 g/day to 4 g/day using a potassium-supplemented salt substitute significantly lowered blood pressure and reduced cardiovascular disease and death. However, the feasibility and safety of achieving sodium intakes below 1.5 g/day remain uncertain.
population_specificity: Chinese adults with excess baseline sodium intake.
effective_dosage: Dietary sodium intake reduced from ~5 g/day to ~4 g/day.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the frequency of self-monitoring tool usage in low-sodium diet interventions and its association with self-efficacy in chronic kidney disease patients.
results_summary: Large variations in self-monitoring frequency were observed, with highest usage in the first month followed by sharp declines. Low baseline self-efficacy was associated with higher tool usage in one intervention, but no significant link was found between usage frequency and self-efficacy improvement over time.
population_specificity: Adult Dutch patients with chronic kidney disease (eGFR ≥ 20-25 mL/min/1.73 m²).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the long-term therapeutic effects and safety of COX inhibitors (e.g., indomethacin) in managing Gitelman syndrome (GS), particularly in pediatric patients.
results_summary: The study found that long-term indomethacin therapy improved hypokalemia and growth retardation in a pediatric GS patient, with manageable gastrointestinal side effects. Genetic testing confirmed the diagnosis after initial misdiagnosis as Bartter syndrome.
population_specificity: A 4-year-old boy (later followed until 14.8 years) with Gitelman syndrome.
effective_dosage: 37.5 mg/d divided tid (low dose of indomethacin).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the tolerability, acceptability, and metabolic effects (R-βHB and glucose responses) of ketone monoester (KME) and ketone monoester/salt (KMES) formulations at two dosages (5 g and 10 g) versus a placebo control.
results_summary: Both KME and KMES increased circulating R-βHB concentrations dose-dependently, with similar peak levels but slight timing differences (KME10 peaked at 15 min, KMES10 at 30 min). KMES had slightly higher acceptability due to fewer aftertaste reports and more frequent appetite suppression compared to KME.
population_specificity: 14 healthy young adults (age 21 ± 2 years, weight 69.7 ± 14.2 kg, body fat 28.1 ± 9.3%).
effective_dosage: 5 g and 10 g total R-βHB (single dose per condition).
study_duration: Acute effects measured over 120 minutes post-ingestion.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the role of dexamethasone in modulating salt and water transport across the airway epithelium in severe COVID-19.
results_summary: The study found that dexamethasone modulates ion channel activity, enhancing sodium ion absorption via ENaC, which may help regulate airway surface liquid volume and mitigate pulmonary oedema in severe COVID-19.
population_specificity: Severe COVID-19 patients with hyperactive immune responses and pulmonary complications.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the content and level of pre-discharge knowledge among hospitalized heart failure patients, particularly regarding salt and fluid management.
results_summary: The study found that heart failure patients had low knowledge levels about fluid and salt management, with factors like educational background and previous hospitalizations influencing knowledge levels. Higher knowledge was associated with better compliance and self-care.
population_specificity: Hospitalized heart failure patients.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate a unique variant of alopecia areata (AA) resembling frontal fibrosing alopecia (FFA) and determine its underlying pathological mechanism.
results_summary: The study identified a variant of AA characterized by single hairs and increased telogen hair follicles, with minimal inflammation. Despite clinical similarity to FFA, histopathology differed, and response to conventional therapy was poor.
population_specificity: Eighteen patients presenting with receding hairline and single hairs.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the role of salt in hypertension, focusing on its effects on the immune system, gut microbiome, and inflammation, and to identify potential biomarkers and therapeutic targets for salt-sensitive hypertension.
results_summary: The study found that high-salt intake is linked to immune system activation, gut dysbiosis, inflammation, oxidative stress, and elevated blood pressure, contributing to salt-sensitive hypertension and related organ damage.
population_specificity: Hypertensive and normotensive individuals, with specific focus on those exhibiting salt sensitivity of blood pressure.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to summarize the cost-effectiveness evidence of salt-reduction strategies as part of preventive interventions for non-communicable diseases in Southeast Asia.
results_summary: The study found that salt-reduction strategies were shown to be cost-effective in several settings, particularly in preventing cardiovascular diseases and hypertension. However, the efficacy varied depending on the specific context and implementation.
population_specificity: Low- and middle-income countries in Southeast Asia.

study_goal: The researchers were attempting to determine the efficacy and safety of intravitreal triamcinolone acetonide (TA) injection for suppressing traumatic proliferative vitreoretinopathy (TPVR) in open globe injury (OGI) patients.
results_summary: The study found that TA injection significantly reduced TPVR severity, improved visual acuity, and increased retinal attachment rates compared to the control group, with no significant difference in macular repositioning or PVR recurrence. Temporary intraocular pressure elevation occurred in one TA-treated eye.
population_specificity: 68 patients with zone III open globe injuries.
study_duration: Intervention administered at the end of emergency surgery, with outcomes assessed during vitrectomy 10±3 days later and follow-up at 6 months.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effectiveness of a salt reduction-specific program versus a general healthy lifestyle program in reducing blood pressure.
results_summary: The salt reduction program effectively lowered blood pressure, particularly in individuals with high-normal BP or hypertension, showing greater improvements than the general lifestyle program. Both programs showed some BP improvements, but the salt-focused approach had more pronounced effects.
population_specificity: 311 adults with a median age of 44 years (IQR 34-54 years).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate cases of peripheral neuropathy of unknown etiology and their potential responsiveness to thiamine administration in a population consuming polished rice and traditional salt tea.
results_summary: The study found that thiamine deficiency-related neuropathy presented with predominant lower limb weakness, with responders showing lower thiamine levels and higher partial pressure of oxygen and lactate levels. Clinical improvement was observed within 24 hours, but proximal muscle weakness persisted longer.
population_specificity: Adult patients in Kashmir presenting with weakness consistent with thiamine deficiency-related neuropathy, all of whom consumed polished rice and traditional salt tea.

study_goal: The abstract does not specify any research goal related to Salt.
results_summary: The abstract does not provide any results related to Salt.
population_specificity: Not specified.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to validate the efficacy and tolerability of a novel antioxidant serum containing sodium ascorbate (a sodium salt of Vit C) for addressing facial photodamage while stimulating elastin and collagen production.
results_summary: The study found significant improvements in facial photodamage parameters, excellent tolerability, and increased elastin and collagen production after 12 weeks of use. Subject satisfaction remained high throughout the study.
population_specificity: 36 participants (35 female, 1 male), aged 38-69 years, with Fitzpatrick skin types II-V and moderate to severe facial photodamage.
effective_dosage: Topical antioxidant serum applied twice daily.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the relationship between glomerular hyperfiltration (GHF) and increased mortality risk, emphasizing the need for better clinical recognition and management strategies, including sodium (Na) restriction.
results_summary: The study found that higher glomerular filtration rate (GFR) values (106.6–113.7 ml/min) are associated with increased mortality risk, even in non-albuminuric patients, and highlighted the importance of Na restriction as part of general measures to mitigate GHF effects.
population_specificity: Diabetic and non-diabetic populations, including obese individuals, essential hypertensives, smokers, and those with fatty liver.

study_goal: The researchers were attempting to determine the effectiveness of mobile technology devices with built-in decision prompts for improving vocational skills in students with ASD and/or IDD, including tasks like filling salt and pepper shakers.
results_summary: The study found that both Apple iPads and Windows-based tablets significantly improved independent vocational performance, with participants self-fading prompt dependence as skill acquisition increased. The multimedia prompting system enhanced task completion and reduced reliance on technological support.
population_specificity: Secondary students with autism spectrum disorder (ASD) and/or intellectual and developmental disability (IDD).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to provide an update on recent developments in hypertension management, including new data to inform the debate on salt's role in hypertension.
results_summary: The abstract mentions "interesting new data to inform the great salt debate," but no specific findings about salt's effects are detailed.
population_specificity: Not specified (general clinical audience).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review advancements in single-cell modification strategies for probiotics to improve their therapeutic efficacy in treating inflammatory bowel disease (IBD).
